oai_dc:dc.dc:title: William Jennings Bryan's death certificate
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Death certificates
Death certificates; Bryan, William Jennings, 1860-1925
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The official certificate of death for William Jennings Bryan. Bryan died in Dayton, Tennessee, on July 26, 1925. The stated cause of death was sudden opoplexy [sic]. The certificate gives the date, location, time and cause of death. Additionally, it contains biographical information such as age, birthplace, name of parents, and place of burial.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: State of Tennessee, Department of Public Health, Bureau of Vital Statistics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Jennings Bryan, venerated orator, served as the lead prosecutor in the Scopes "Monkey Trial" in July 1925. He died in Dayton, Tennessee, five days after the conclusion of the trial. A three-time United States Democratic nominee for President, Bryan's progressive politics as well as his consistent defense of the ordinary American earned him the moniker "the Great Commoner."
